title: Ethanol and HBr Kinetics and IMFs

content.question: For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. Ethanol (<math alttext="C 2 H 5 O H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>5</mn></msub><mi>OH</mi></math>) reacts with hydrobromic acid (<math alttext="H B r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>HBr</mi></math>) to produce ethyl bromide (<math alttext="C 2 H 5 B r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>5</mn></msub><mi>Br</mi></math>) and water according to the following balanced equation. <math alttext="C 2 H 5 O H, plus H B r, reacts to produce, C 2 H 5 B r, plus H 2 O" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>5</mn></msub><mi>OH</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>HBr</mi><mo>→</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>5</mn></msub><mi>Br</mi><mo>+</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></math> (a) At the conclusion of the reaction, the product mixture includes <math alttext="C 2 H 5 B r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>5</mn></msub><mi>Br</mi></math>, <math alttext="H 2 O" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></math>, and excess unreacted <math alttext="C 2 H 5 O H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>5</mn></msub><mi>OH</mi></math>.(i) Identify all of the types of intermolecular forces that can exist between one molecule of <math alttext="C 2 H 5 O H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>5</mn></msub><mi>OH</mi></math> and one molecule of <math alttext="C 2 H 5 B r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>5</mn></msub><mi>Br</mi></math> in the product mixture.

You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. Ethanol (<math alttext="C 2 H 5 O H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>5</mn></msub><mi>OH</mi></math>) reacts with hydrobromic acid (<math alttext="H B r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>HBr</mi></math>) to produce ethyl bromide (<math alttext="C 2 H 5 B r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>5</mn></msub><mi>Br</mi></math>) and water according to the following balanced equation. <math alttext="C 2 H 5 O H, plus H B r, reacts to produce, C 2 H 5 B r, plus H 2 O" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>5</mn></msub><mi>OH</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>HBr</mi><mo>→</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>5</mn></msub><mi>Br</mi><mo>+</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></math> (a) At the conclusion of the reaction, the product mixture includes <math alttext="C 2 H 5 B r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>5</mn></msub><mi>Br</mi></math>, <math alttext="H 2 O" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></math>, and excess unreacted <math alttext="C 2 H 5 O H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>5</mn></msub><mi>OH</mi></math>.(i) Identify all of the types of intermolecular forces that can exist between one molecule of <math alttext="C 2 H 5 O H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>5</mn></msub><mi>OH</mi></math> and one molecule of <math alttext="C 2 H 5 B r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>5</mn></msub><mi>Br</mi></math> in the product mixture.

(ii) The aqueous solubility of <math alttext="C 2 H 5 O H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>5</mn></msub><mi>OH</mi></math> is greater than that of <math alttext="C 2 H 5 B r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>5</mn></msub><mi>Br</mi></math>. Explain this observation based on the types and relative strengths of intermolecular forces between each solute and <math alttext="H 2 O" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></math>.

The reaction is found to be first order with respect to <math alttext="H B r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>HBr</mi></math> when <math alttext="C 2 H 5 O H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>5</mn></msub><mi>OH</mi></math> is in excess. The following data were recorded showing how the concentration of <math alttext="H B r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>HBr</mi></math> changes over time.Time <math alttext="in minutes" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mtext>min</mtext><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math><math alttext="0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0</mn></math><math alttext="50.0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>50.0</mn></math><math alttext="100.0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>100.0</mn></math><math alttext="150.0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>150.0</mn></math><math alttext="200.0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>200.0</mn></math><math alttext="the molar concentration of H B r, in moles per liter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi>HBr</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>M</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math><math alttext="2.00" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2.00</mn></math><math alttext="1.80" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.80</mn></math><math alttext="1.62" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.62</mn></math><math alttext="1.46" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.46</mn></math><math alttext="1.32" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.32</mn></math>(b) Using the data provided, calculate the value of the rate constant, <math alttext="k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>k</mi></math>, in <math alttext="minutes to the negative 1 power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mtext>min</mtext><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></math>.
(c) Using the data provided, determine the half-life of the reaction, in minutes.
(d) The experiment is repeated at a higher temperature.(i) Explain the effect, if any, that the higher temperature has on collisions between reactant particles.
(ii) Identify the effect, if any, that the higher temperature has on the rate constant. Explain your reasoning.

(e) The following reaction mechanism has been proposed for the reaction of <math alttext="C 2 H 5 O H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>5</mn></msub><mi>OH</mi></math> and <math alttext="H B r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>HBr</mi></math>.Step 1:<math alttext="C 2 H 5 O H, plus H 3 O with a positive 1 charge, is in equilibrium with C 2 H 5 O H 2 with a positive 1 charge, plus H 2 O" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>5</mn></msub><mi>OH</mi><mo> </mo><mo>+</mo><mo> </mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mo>+</mo></msup><mo>⇄</mo><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>5</mn></msub><msup><msub><mi>OH</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>+</mo></msup><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mo>+</mo><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></math>fast<math alttext="delta H sub 1, is greater than 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>H</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></math>Step 2:<math alttext="C 2 H 5 O H 2 with a positive 1 charge, plus B r with a negative 1 charge, reacts to produce, C 2 H 5 B r, plus H 2 O" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>5</mn></msub><msup><msub><mi>OH</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>+</mo></msup><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mo>+</mo><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><msup><mi>Br</mi><mo>-</mo></msup><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mo>→</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>5</mn></msub><mi>Br</mi><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mo>+</mo><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></math>slow<math alttext="delta H sub 2, is less than 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo><</mo><mn>0</mn></math>Overall:<math alttext="C 2 H 5 O H, plus H 3 O with a positive 1 charge, plus B r with a negative 1 charge, reacts to produce, C 2 H 5 B r, plus 2 H 2 O" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>5</mn></msub><mi>OH</mi><mo> </mo><mo>+</mo><mo> </mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mo>+</mo></msup><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mo>+</mo><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><msup><mi>Br</mi><mo>-</mo></msup><mo> </mo><mo>→</mo><mo> </mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>5</mn></msub><mi>Br</mi><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mo>+</mo><mspace width="0.4em"></mspace><mn>2</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></math><math alttext="delta H sub reaction, is less than 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>H</mi><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub><mo><</mo><mn>0</mn></math>(i) Sketch an energy diagram that represents this reaction mechanism on the axes given.

(ii) In step 2 of the mechanism, only the <math alttext="C to O single" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mo lspace="0.05em" rspace="0.05em">-</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></math> bond is broken and the <math alttext="C to B r single" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mo lspace="0.05em" rspace="0.05em">-</mo><mi>Br</mi></math> bond is formed. Given that <math alttext="delta H sub 2, is less than 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo><</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, a student claims that more energy is needed to break the <math alttext="C to O single" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mo lspace="0.05em" rspace="0.05em">-</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></math> bond than is released when the <math alttext="C to B r single" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mo lspace="0.05em" rspace="0.05em">-</mo><mi>Br</mi></math> bond forms. Do you agree or disagree? Justify your answer.

(iii) The following Lewis diagram is for the reaction intermediate, <math alttext="C 2 H 5 O H 2 with a positive 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>5</mn></msub><msup><msub><mi>OH</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>+</mo></msup></math>. On the Lewis diagram, circle an atom that has a formal charge of <math alttext="positive 1" overflow="scroll"><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></math>.

skill.text: 1.B: Describe the components of and quantitative information from models and representations that illustrate both particulate-level and macroscopic- level properties.
